article.headline: âWhat a lost opportunityâ: Uberâs abandonment of GrubHub deal is a âclear negative,â analysts say
article.body: The food-delivery landscape is getting a shakeup, but not in the way investors had been expecting over the past few weeks. European player Just Eat Takeaway.com N.V. JET, +1.22% Â TKWY, +1.00% Â confirmed Wednesday afternoon that it would be acquiring GrubHub Inc. GRUB, +0.83% Â in an all-stock deal. Uber Technologies Inc. UBER, -0.18% Â was thought to be close to its own deal for GrubHub recently, but the ride-hailing giant reportedly backed away due to the potential for antitrust opposition to the combination. Opinion: Uber plus Grubhub called âa new low in pandemic profiteering,â and thatâs not the only problem Analysts mostly agreed that missing out on a GrubHub deal was unfortunate for Uber, even though some saw a few silver linings. âUber walking away at the altar from the GrubHub deal is a clear negative as competition and pricing pressure will be fierce going forward,â Wedbush analysts Daniel Ives and Ygal Arounian. âGrubHub being acquired by a larger competitor will only embolden the market-share battle just at the same time that the regulatory environment around delivery fees across cities is becoming a larger headwind.â They continue to rate Uberâs stock at outperform with a $47 price target. Deutsche Bankâs Lloyd Walmsley also wrote that the lack of an Uber-GrubHub deal is a âclear negativeâ for Uber that will slow down âwhat looked likely to be a fast-track towards rationalization in the market and path towards profitability.â âWhat a lost opportunity,â he said in his note to clients. At the same time, he wrote that he spoke with Uberâs investor relations team after the Just Eat Takeaway.com announcement took place and âcame away with a better understanding for their rationale and some confidence that this is mostly a bump in the road.â He wrote that in his view, Uberâs inability to reach a deal with GrubHub seemed to hinge on more than just disputes about a reverse break-up fee. Other concerns may have included âunsavory tactics at GrubHub that might have to be discontinuedâ and âmarketplace fee caps in NYC and elsewhere that could ultimately get made permanent,â he argued. Walmsley rates Uber shares a buy with a $40 price target. Todd Holman, a director at Union Square Advisors, said that for Uber Eats and Doordash, GrubHubâs tie up with a well-funded European player is âif not the worst case scenario, one they donât want to wake up and see.â Consolidation to only two major players wouldâve allowed those two companies to focus on the cities where they were already best positioned and then âreally begin to crank on profitability,â he told MarketWatch. GrubHub seemed to be letting up on some of its marketing efforts in recent months in an attempt to control spending, but Just Eat Takeaway is âmuch better prepared an willing to continue this market-share battle.â MKM Partners analyst Rohit Kulkarni called the GrubHub-Just Eat merger a âa marginal negative for Uber shares over the near-term as we think this was a lost opportunity to become a market share leader in the U.S.,â though he still sees a window for Uber Eats to grow its share over the next year as the GrubHubâs new merger arrangement âgoes through the digestion process.â He rates Uber shares a buy with a $38 target price. Opinion: IBM, Amazon moves on facial recognition are good baby steps toward removing bias Bernsteinâs Mark Shmulik was more mixed on the situation. âOur confidence in Uber management continues to grow,â he wrote. âWe didnât want to see Uber overpay for GrubHub, particularly given uncertainty around how regulators would respond to the deal, and weâre happy to see that management stood its ground.â Shmulik said that Just Eatâs offer âfeels expensiveâ given that it and GrubHub operate in different geographies, limiting the opportunity for obvious synergies. Still, heâs concerned that this deal wonât lead to rationalization in the food-delivery industry like there could have been if Uber or a different U.S. player chose to purchase GrubHub. âItâs unlikely that Just Eat would be happy buying the #3 player in the US without wanting to gain share â a new player stepping in is probably bad for competition,â he wrote, while reiterating an outperform rating and $35 target price on Uberâs stock. Uber shares are down about 8% in Thursday trading, while Lyft Inc.âs stock LYFT, +2.16% Â is off roughly 6%. Both companies were dealt a blow to their business models late Wednesday after the California Public Utilities Commission said that ride-sharing drivers were to be classified as employees under the stateâs new law governing gig-economy work. This determination is a âreal headwind to [Uber and Lyft] from a unit-economics standpointâ and will force the companies to determine whether they should make company-wide changes to how drivers are treated or move toward a âpotential patchwork approachâ by preparing to deal with each stateâs potential regulations independently, Holman said. Uberâs stock has added 1.6% over the past month as the S&P 500 has increased 4%.
